key_points: Climate change is significantly disrupting the Earth's water cycle, leading to more extreme weather events.
Increased temperatures result in higher water demand and faster evaporation from reservoirs.
The changes in the climate and water cycles are starting to have severe impacts.
Peter Gleick, a climate scientist, has testified before Congress on these risks, especially to agriculture and access to clean water.
Gleick's research over the years has predicted these changes, many of which are now being observed.
He expressed a sentiment of 'I told you so' regarding the predictions made by climate scientists.
The recognition of these changes serves as vindication for past climate science work.
However, Gleick points out the sadness in realizing that earlier policy actions could have mitigated current impacts.
There's an emphasis on the longstanding and increasing global temperatures.
The article includes a note on region-restricted content related to climate change data.
spokespersons: Peter Gleick (co-founder, Pacific Institute in Oakland, Calif.)
